g:HTMLPanel.p: Request Interceptors allow the manipulation of the requests before they are sent.
You can add custom headers, set the authentication method, timeout, response type, or even change the http method.

Now let's perform a request, and check if the previous interceptor was really applied.
The headers property should contain the header set in the interceptor.
The Request Interceptors are applied following the same order they are registered in the requestor.
g:HTMLPanel.div:
Interceptoring affects later request processing Be aware that request interceptoring is the first processing step of the requests. It affects thus the subsequent serialization and interception.
For example, if you set the Content-Type header in a interceptor, the serialization process, which is performed following, will consider it when serializaring the payload.

g:HTMLPanel.p: Response Interceptors allow manipulation of the responses as soon as they arrive.
You can add custom headers to the responses.
Suppose we register the following response interceptor in the requestor.

Now let's perform a request, and check if the previous interceptor was really applied.
The response should contain the header set in the interceptor, but the request shouldn't.
Notice in you browser dev tools that the request didn't contain the custom header. It was added programmatically after the response has arrived.
The Response Interceptors are applied following the same order they are registered in the requestor.
g:HTMLPanel.div:
Interceptoring affects later response processing Be aware that response interceptoring is the first processing step of the responses. It affects thus the subsequent interception and deserialization.
For example, if you set the Content-Type header in a response interceptor, the deserialization process will consider it when deserializaring the payload.
